repnme.cdata!: Comoros - Population and Human Resources Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings gave mixed results,
            for although the outcome of the project is unsatisfactory,
            and its sustainability unlikely, institutional development
            impacts were substantial, and the Bank's performance
            was satisfactory based on good project preparation,
            appraisal, and supervision. Conversely, the Borrower's
            performance was unsatisfactory, based on the
            Government's inability to strengthen macroeconomic
            policies. Lessons drawn from the project are as follows.
            First, social sector projects in Comoros should reinforce -
            and include in project design - the need for dynamic local
            communities to participate in the mobilization of human
            resources; thus, the country should envisage reforms to
            reduce civil service, and instead increase the ratio of
            government revenues to GDP, beyond fifteen percent. Second,
            the approach taken in testing sub-project preparation,
            financing, and supervision, before committing a large amount
            of resources proved highly successful, i.e., the Social Fund
            was prepared before Board approval of the project, was
            highly successful, and its implementation progressed
            smoothly. However, operating costs for a newly established
            Social Fund, within the context of the Comoros, is
            supposedly high, a fact which although legitimate, increased
            unexpected administrative costs. And third, beneficiary cost
            sharing, enabled the health system to continue operations,
            despite the lack of government funding.

18155492.trustfund:
TF021440-SOCIAL DIMENSIONS OF ADJUSTMENT,TF028001-FAC CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF021345-POPULATION & HUMAN
            RESOURCES PROJECT

repnme.cdata!: Comoros - Population and Human Resources Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the project is
            to strengthen the development of human resources in the
            Comoros by: (a) increasing the efficiency and effectiveness
            of basic health services, through the establishment of
            efficient regional health administrations and other
            supportive services, which will be capable of providing
            comprehensive good quality and cost effective health care;
            these will include family planning services and Acquired
            Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) prevention, and will
            involve community participation, self-management and cost
            recovery; and (b) promoting complementary community
            development initiatives to develop social infrastructure and
            grassroots participation in small-scale productive
            activities, through a Community Development Support Fund
            (CDSF). The project has two components: population and
            health; and community development. The population and health
            component will build upon existing successful pilot programs
            for self-management and cost-recovery to establish services
            capable of ensuring cost-effective and sustainable provision
            of comprehensive and good quality health care, including
            family planning and AIDS control services. To that end, the
            component will: (a) strengthen the capacities of the three
            health regions to plan, implement, administer, and supervise
            health care services, in part through improving and
            expanding the training of district health personnel; (ii)
            equip and rehabilitate two regional hospitals and a number
            of health centers; and (iii) promote family planning and
            AIDS control services. In the second component,
            complementary community development activities as well as
            activities to encourage sustainable economic development
            will be supported through a CDSF. While demand driven, the
            CDSF will focus primarily on: training of communities and
            groups in micro-project development, management, and
            implementation; rehabilitation of social infastructure
            (especially primary schools, water supply, and health
            posts); activities to promote the well-being and development
            of women; and income generating activities.
